Equations with an infinite number of solutions

Some pairs of simultaneous equations can possess an innite number of solutions. Consider the following example.

Example

Solve the equations.

\(2x + y = 8\)   (11)

\(4x + 2y = 16\)   (12)

Solution

If Equation (11) is multiplied by 2 we find both equations are identical:

\(4x + 2y = 16\).

This means that one of them is redundant and we need only consider the single equation<\p>

\(2x + y = 8\)

There are infinitely many pairs of values of \(x\) and \(y\) which satisfy this equation. For example, if \(x=0\) then \(y=8\), if \(x=1\) then \(y=6\), and if \(x=-3\) then \(y=14\). We could continue like this producing more and more solutions. Suppose we choose a value, say \(\lambda\), for \(x\). We can then write

\(2\lambda + y = 8\) so that \(y= 8-2\lambda\)

The solution is therefore \(x=\lambda\), \(y=8-2\lambda\) for any value of \(\lambda\) whatsoever. There are an infinite number of such solutions.
